data.title: Can't pass in harmony flags in extension development.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Sorry if this is the wrong place to ask this, but I can't find anywhere else to ask!

I'm trying to develop an extension with Typescript/ES6. It all goes well until I want to use a feature that requires a harmony flag, like `--harmony-default-parameters`, because I have no clue where to pass in that flag. I tried this in my launch.json:

```
"runtimeArgs": ["--harmony-default-parameters"],
```

but it seems to just be ignored. 

The only vaguely similar issue I found was #1568, which claims a fix in the January release. I'm running the most recent Visual Studio Code Insiders build, so if that was indeed the same issue (I'm not sure if it is), then I'm still running into the same problem. 

Thanks!

data.title: ITextFileService#saveAs() should go through textFileEditorModel.save()
data.body: In an extension, the callback registered in `workspace.onDidSaveTextDocument()` does not get called after  `vscode.window.activeTextEditor.document.save()` has been called when `activeTextEditor.document` is a new untitled document. The "Save As" dialog appears, I enter a filename and click save. The file gets saved (and closed) but the registered callback doesn't get called. Is this intentional behavior?

data.title: Configure user task runner

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Would it be possible to have a user defined task runner as opposed to a workspace `tasks.json`? Similar to `settings.json` that sits next to `keybindings.json` and the snippets folder.

Would allow me to not having to define a default task runner (I run GNU Global `gtags` for each project) for every single project root I work in.

data.title: Accents (´`¨^, others?) are inserted in the wrong position (Mac)
data.body:
Whenever I want to enter a back-tick (`) in OS X, I usually just press the accent key without explicitly selecting space as the accented character. (If my next action - mouse or keyboard - is not to select an accent-able character, space is implicitly selected for me.) This normally works as expected in VS Code, but not when I immediately move the cursor with the arrow keys.

If I press any arrow key directly after pressing the accent key, the text cursor is moved _first_. _Then_ the backtick is inserted in the new position. (It's apparently accenting the _move cursor_ control character!?) This gets even worse if I happen to hold down the shift key as I press the arrow key. That action selects text, which is then overwritten by the back-tick!

This happens equally for both acute and grave accent characters (´, `), as well as circumflex (^) and umlaut (¨). (I don't know what other accent characters to test, but I assume this issue applies to all of them.)

data.title: Need API to for lines visible in viewport
data.body:
Cursor Commands
- [x] Move to view line start `g0`
- [x] Select till line start `vg0`
- [x] Move to view line first non white space character `g^`
- [x] Select till line first non white space character `vg^`
- [x] Move to view line end `g$`
- [x] Select till view line end `vg$`
- [x] Move to view line last non white space character `g_`
- [x] Select till view line last non white space character `vg_`
- [x] Move to view line middle `gm`
- [x] Select till view line middle `vgm`
- [x] Move up `N` view lines `gk`
- [x] Select till `N` view lines up `vgk`
- [x] Move down `N` view lines `gj`
- [x] Select till `N` view lines down `vgj`
- [x] Move to first non white space character of Nth line from the top of the view `H`
- [x] Select till first non white space character of Nth line from the top of the view `vH`
- [x] Move to first non white space character of center line of the view `M`
- [x] Select till first non white space character of center line of the view `vM`
- [x] Move to first non white space character of Nth line from the bottom of the view `L`
- [x] Select till first non white space character of Nth line from the bottom of the view `vL`

vi has [`H`, `M`, and `L` keybindings](http://vimdoc.sourceforge.net/htmldoc/motion.html#H) that move the cursor based what lines are currently on screen.  It's not possible for a Vim-like extension to implement these right now, because the the vscode extension APIs don't expose this information.

data.title: Feature request: command to hard wrap text block at certain column (Sublime Text: cmd+shift+Q)
data.body:
This is a followup from [vscode-go/#113](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/issues/113). In Sublime Text, if I place the cursor in a paragraph, or select a block of text, and press cmd+shift+Q, it will hard-wrap the paragraph/block at the currently defined wrap column. It also preserves comment semantics, i.e. prefix or block-level comment definitions.

![fwmzg5jcdg](http://g.recordit.co/fwmzG5JCdg.gif)

This feature is incredibly valuable.

data.body:
```
// in file serve-static.js
require('serve-static')()

```

> Cannot invoke an expression whose type lacks a call signature.

Possibly related to #999

data.title: Add posibility for a language to define indentation settings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is a followup from [vscode-go/#191](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/issues/191).

Go uses tabs for indention, and spaces for alignment. When I open a .go file and press tab, for example selecting a block of text and tabbing to indent, spaces are inserted instead. I can't think of a situation when I want the tab key to insert spaces in a .go file. Can the autodetection algorithm be improved in this case?

(As an aside, thanks for this project! I'm really enjoying it so far.)

data.title: Code Opens Behind File Explorer
data.body: When I am in the File Explorer, and I open a file by right clicking and selecting `Open With -> Code` it opens behind the File Explorer.

data.title: Renaming class file
data.body: When I'm renaming file which have class A, then in renamed file it alerts that class a already exists in other file, but after reopening VS-Code it stops alerting.

data.title: Dark+/Light+: Please add color for keyword.operator
data.body: Themes like Monokai, colorize tokens tagged as `keyword.operator` i.e. the operators. It would be nice to be able to have this in the default Dark+/Light+ themes as well. I current have to workaround this by setting operators as `keyword.other` which doesn;t distinguish operators from normal keywords such as `class`.

data.title: Error to open an editor of different kind closes previous editor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
When you have a split editor open and one of the editors has focus when you click on a file that cannot be opened in the editor (e.g. a binary, video... etc.) then that editor will close as you receive the error message.  Let's keep it open with the file you had open before you tried to open the un-openable file.

![feb 05 2016 23 07](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11839736/12865313/5242ae10-cc5d-11e5-8947-dcab3802ce3c.gif)

data.title: Is it possible to extend the colorizer for markdown in an extension?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I read in the [Common Questions](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/customization/colorizer#_common-questions) that the markdown colorizer cannot be **overridden**.
However, I don't want to override it.
Instead I want to overlay additional syntax highlighting.
In particular, I want to be able to colorize [custom extensions](https://github.com/Azure/azure-content/blob/master/contributor-guide/custom-markdown-extensions.md) to markdown such as the ones use by azure.com:
`> [AZURE.NOTE] some text`

I don't think this is possible based on what I've read and some meager experimenting, but I wanted to ask just in case.

My goal is make it easier to identify syntax errors in the custom extension. My fallback is to write a language server that will validate, but I think that colorizing is perforable.

data.title: Adding a command bar
data.body: is there a way to create command bar similar to "Debug Console", which is always visible in the bottom for running commands (Emacs/vi style)?

data.title: Generator Syntax Highlighting Broken
data.body:
Theme: Colorful Default Themes (Dark)

There is still a small issue when syntax highlighting generators, as you can see from this screenshot:

![screenshot from 2016-02-05 21-15-55](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1571806/12864356/b47a6542-cc4d-11e5-812b-117e9e6b036b.png)

When using a generator, everything becomes white. Also the class definition in the foreach is also white.

data.title: Allow for empty editor panes

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: Is there a way to configure VSCode, so that it always shows a fixed number of pane? Or keep the pane even when there is no open file. Something like

data.title: Provide a setting to add each opened file as pinned editor
data.body:
There is  key bindings `⌘K Enter` to `Add to Working Files`. Is is possible to update some settings to add file to `Working Files` by default when the file is opened in editor?

Many a time I open files just for reference, and since I have not performed any action on the file, it does not get added to `Working Files`. 
If I switch to another file, and want to switch to the previous file, I got to search and open the file again.
If any opened file, would get added to `Working Files`, accessing it again, would be easy in large code bases.

Thanks!!

data.title: Node debugger stalls when using util.inspect
data.body:
Debugging a Node program that uses [util.inspect](https://nodejs.org/api/util.html#util_util_inspect_object_options) hangs the underlying node process.

I stumbled across this while working on an app that depends on the Azure Storage SDK for Node (it uses util.inspect). I don't have a workaround for debugging right now, but the app works fine when running directly from the command line.

I've created a repro of the problem here:
https://gist.github.com/benquarmby/36f6c00947ad04509212

Steps:
- Create a script that invokes util.inspect on an object
- Place a breakpoint in the script _after_ the call util.inspect
- Start debugging
- Observe that the breakpoint is not hit

Environment:
- VSCode 0.10.6
- Windows 10 x64
- Node 5.5 x64

data.title: PHP - Return type and scalar type parameters (flagged as error)
data.body:
Two bugs here that need addressing.

First, VS Code incorrectly flags any PHP function with a return type as an error: 
`parse error, expecting '';'' or ''{''`

Example of a valid PHP function with a return type (VS Code flags it as being an error):
`public static function HashPassword(string $password) : string { ... }`

Second, VS Code incorrectly flags any PHP function with a strictly typed parameter which has a default value as an error:
`Default value for parameters with a class type hint can only be NULL`

Example of a valid PHP function with a strictly typed parameter which has a default (VS Code flags it as being an error):
`public static function CreatePassword(int $characterCount = 30) : string { ... }`

Code tested successfully in PHP 7.

data.title: debugProtocol update: Add types for function breakpoints
data.body:
I did not push this change because it introduces one small incompatibility that needs adoption.
In the Breakpoint type (that is returned form the setBreakpointRequests), the `line` attribute is now optional (like `column`) because function breakpoints do not necessarily provide line information on verification.

data.title: Right Click > Open in Command Prompt state is not helpful
data.body:
when you right click Open in Command Prompt on a folder in VS Code the resulting command prompt does not pull in system/user environment variables, meaning I see the default $p$g prompt, none of my stuff is accessible via Path as it didn't get my Path, etc etc.

this is not an issue via Windows Explorer when Shift Right Click > Open command window here. Only via Code.

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body:
Is there a reason why we leave it this way?  I have to frequently manually reopen the file I was working on, or else I'm trapped in the diff view even after leaving Git.
